INTRODUCTION:Command and Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is a real-time strategy game that was developed and published by Electronic Arts mostly due to the acquisition of Westwood Studios by EA and Westwood's closure back in 2003. This game continues the Tiberian Sun story arc and is a direct sequel to Tiberian Sun & its expansion Tiberian Sun: Firestorm.

Following the franchise tradition, this title follows the story of the almost never ending conflict between the Global Defense Initiative (GDI) and an international paramilitary / militant religious organization called the Brotherhood of Nod. Unlike its predecessors however, this game introduces a new faction in an effort by EA to add more gameplay diversity. The new faction is known as the Scrin.

PROS:+ The game has good art style and graphics: (Both of which aged really well specially since this game was released back in 2008.)
+ Very good Sound design and unit voice acting.
+ Quality live action cinematic played by very well known Hollywood stars and the ever iconic Joseph D. Kucan as “Kane.”
+ Lengthy Campaign for each of the factions (about 20 hours if you play them in the Very Hard difficulty setting)
+ Great story that is interwoven with each faction (meaning that each faction “wins” in their own right)
+ New Faction that is fun to play and comes with an unlockable Campaign once you finish both GDI and NOD campaigns.
+ Old factions (GDI and NOD) has been revamped with new units and playstyles without deviating from their respective origin stories.
+ Fast paced and intense action.
+ Lore heavy with story continuity from the old games.
+ Fun and challenging missions during the campaign.
+ Revamped game mechanics such as squad based infantry, super unit capture etc.

CONS:- No online multiplayer due to GameSpy shutdown: FIX[cnc-online.net]
- Some unit pathfinding quirks
- Some balance issues (specially with the super units)
- Relatively small maps
- Limited tech-tree options and build orders
- Campaign strategic options has no real effect
- Random difficulty spikes between the campaign missions

NEUTRAL+/- Mission objectives are immediately marked in the map thus depriving the player of map exploration. A.K.A. spoon feeding the player enemy locations.

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME that captures the fun and excitement of the old C&C games while adding its own modern ideas to mix thus making for a wonderful and action packed RTS experience.

WORTH IT?The game at full price is $15 (or your regional equivalent) thus its a must have for RTS fans and Command & Conquer fans a like.

Again I have to stress out that the official multiplayer servers are now permanently offline so you'll have to use CNC:Online[cnc-online.net]  if you want to experience the game's online multiplayer feature.

reviewText:
I have long been a Command & Conquer fan, starting with Command & Conquer: Red Alert as one of the first PC games I experienced and have since loved to this day. I will side with many others in appreciation of what Command & Conquer 3 accomplished; a return to its roots from the brief transitional period of Generals and stupendous execution of it, at that.

Command & Conquer 3, as such, uses a far different method of base construction and economy as compared to traditional real-time strategy games; rather than workers, it relies on the construction yard as both the player's nerve center and primary construction unit. Buildings can be placed in control zones after they have been fully purchased, and are instantly constructed when placed. The player's economy functions through tiberium harvesters, which comb through a field of radioactive crystals rather than attaching themselves to a resource node. For 2007, even though it recalled much of older times in the RTS genre, it was quite a unique game.

Gameplay-wise, Command & Conquer 3 is a frantic game of hard counters. Anti-tank troops will rarely be able to take on rifle squads alone, and machine gun turrets will lose handily to main battle tanks. Units can vanish in the blink of an eye without warning, be it from high-potency artillery or sniper ambushes on isolated units. Economy plays a central role, as well; the player who establishes a powerful economy quickly and staunchly will often be the victor, as Command & Conquer games have never featured a supply cap or need for supply structures.

For some, this can be a headache. The leading role of economy, knowing troops will often die even with your keenest intervention, and the balancing act of fending off enemy counters in such a fast-paced environment leaves little room for the overly thorough in high-stakes games. Even a strong commander will find themselves in an unenviable position should they lose the economy war, as the frustration of losing harvesters on a stressed budget and watching one's veteran units dwindle with each skirmish can hardly be called a calming state of affairs. Some consider the workerless method of base construction to be backwards and that the over-reliance on economy to decide games is detrimental to the skill involved in playing the game.

In terms of storyline, Command & Conquer has always managed to captivate me. It may be nostalgia ballooning the series' writing and acting beyond what it should be, but the plot surrounding the intricate game of cat-and-mouse between GDI and Kane, the corruption of the planet by tiberium (most pointedly, the chilling depictions of red zones), and the live action cutscenes have all served to inspire me on many different levels. Command & Conquer 3's introduction of the Visitors and Kane's prophecy of their arrival have all served to bolster my apprecation of the storyline - C&C4 kept firmly out of mind.

While it is unfortunate that Frank Klepacki did not return to grant C&C3 a score similar to the stupendous soundtracks of Red Alert 2 and prior, Steve Jablonsky and Trevor Morris lived up to his quality - if not necessarily style - and brought quality music to the title. Voice acting is more a toss-up, however; while most units offer fitting and well-acted lines, some - most notably Nod's two early scouting vehicles - are overacted to the verge of ridiculousness. Acting, while somewhat overdone in some areas, is enjoyable and mostly believable, and Joseph Kucan's applaudable return as Kane once more can hardly go without notice.

Graphics and general sound quality are another toss-up, however. The SAGE engine - used originally for Generals in 2004 - was dated by 2007 standards, especially compared with the Essence engine used by Relic Entertainment in Company of Heroes a year prior. While effects and asset quality are undoubtedly good for their time, the SAGE engine often struggles to keep up, and some oddities can occur from certain situations. Notably, infantry cycling through take cover" shouts on death and strangeness surrounding some explosion effects

Edit :- All Online Features of this Game are no Longer in Service.


If you're a fan of the Command & Conquer series, three small words are bound to get you excited: Kane is back. Indeed, so are a good number of beloved series hallmarks, like a huge amount of full-motion video and intense strategic combat. But Tiberium Wars is a lot more than just lip service to franchise enthusiasts, and you don't need the rose-hued glasses of nostalgia to appreciate its polish and intensity. It's simply a superb game that's fun and exciting to play both online and off.

The missions themselves are incredibly varied and involve a lot more than destroying an enemy base or defending a particular structure. You'll have to do these things, of course, but you have both primary and secondary objectives to complete, which include using engineers to capture certain buildings, amassing beam cannons to take out defenses, or teaming up with your sworn enemy to defend against alien attack. You'll be doing it all in a variety of real-world theaters, such as Washington, DC, downtown Sydney, and the eerily dry Amazon basin. The near-future take on familiar locales makes the intense battles feel even more thrilling, because the settings are recognizable and meaningful.

That's not to say the combat isn't gripping on its own. If you're usually content to turtle up in real-time strategy games, you're in for a surprise: Battles are intense and focused, and they give you little time to prepare. Like any RTS, you still need to build up resources, but it's a quick process of plopping down a bunch of tiberium refineries and power generators and finding the action, because if you don't, the action will quickly find you. Once you get past the first two acts of each campaign, you'll discover that Tiberium Wars' artificial intelligence is aggressive and resourceful, and it will take advantage of your strategic flaws. Don't expect to put your trust in one or two favored units, because even the most powerful units have noticeable weaknesses.

It's a rusher's paradise, but you shouldn't take it to mean that technological advancement and thoughtful strategy don't have their places. You won't need to deal with long, complex tech trees, and it makes Tiberium Wars feel somewhat limited in this aspect next to advancement-focused strategy games like Supreme Commander. However, you do have multiple powers and upgrades to earn by building various structures. The powers run the gamut from GDI's powerful ion strike to Nod's vapor bomb, and they fit each faction perfectly. As you use units they level up, making them more effective in battle, and in some cases you improve units by more unconventional means. For example, you can use a Nod warmech to destroy your own flame tank, and the mech will then spew fire in addition to its own native attack.

How differently each faction plays is impressive, especially with the new Scrin faction added to the mix. GDI units tend to be straightforward and powerful, and a huge force of mammoth tanks and juggernauts is a challenge to counter. Nod relies on sneakiness and smart use of unique abilities, and a small force of stealth tanks and viper bombers can cripple an enemy's economy. But playing as the Scrin is Tiberium Wars' greatest delight and challenge, since the alien faction is so different from the others. Your first encounters with the Scrin in the campaign are breathtaking, since even low-level units like buzzers look interesting and intimidating. In fact, the most threatening sight within the game is a fleet of Scrin assault carriers and their accompanying fighters. Yet while the Scrin have some potent units and other advantages, such as the ability to collect endless tiberium without building silos, they require a lot of micromanagement and intimate knowledge of each unit and structure.

Regardless of your history with Kane and his cohorts, Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is one of the finest real-time strategy games in years. It's also a triumphant return to form for the series, because it's more than just a graphical update--it's an exciting, well-tuned experience with enough that's old and enough that's new to thrill old-timers and newcomers alike.

Suffice it to say, you should play this game, and expect to be playing it for a long time to come.

reviewText:
Ignore my hours. I had this game on disk since it first came out, and honestly, its had more time put into it than any of my other strategy games put together.

When Westwood still existed the C&C series always were wonderful to play - There was just that touch of polish and care which went into their games that you didn't quite get with others, even right down to the little animations of the commandos lighting a cigerrette and chucking it aside, quoting one of their infamous lines with a chuckle. So for 2D units  you were commanding quite a colourful and unique army.

However when C&C3 came along... Oohh boy, that jump into 3D. It brought fresh life to the series!
... too bad it was the last 'good' game beyond Red Alert 3 after that. EA had washed everything 'Westwood' down the drain.


As always the three factions are almost brilliantly balanced; They each have strengths and flaws which play a triangular role against one another, with similar but unique powers and tech trees. While they can be infamous for certain reasons - Scrin with their hordes of alien ships for example - there is no reason why a player cannot use either GDI or NOD to the same extent and counter it.

From the previous two games the missions are also once again varied, can last you a while, and the AI can be dubious when you're unprepared, if not a little clumsy around the newly introduced slopes and hills, but you'll soon learn their routines and will be yearning for multiplayer - The true bread and butter of the game.

Modders have gone to town since it was released and patched to 1.9 - Maps. Game Modes. Entire campaign edits. New units, new customisation... Hell, they even have Tiberium Sun mods which adds the old units into the game.


Like I said. Sad to see its the last 'good' game of the series.
Command & Conquer 4 'Twilight' ruined the finale to the story by ripping out the core gameplay mechanics, making maps capture-the-flag esque and point control, while plummeting the player into a final 'thats all folks!' with the ending.
If you want a true C&C game, get Tiberum Dawn or Sun. If you want an enjoyable 3d C&C game, get this, or Red Alert 3.

reviewText:
This is my first review so im glad I picked one of my favorite games to start off with (be warned its long, so if you want to skip to the end it sums up the review) . My hours don't do it justice but rest assured, I had this game for both PS3 and Xbox before buying it once again on Steam (Yes, I loved it that much, also theres no limit on units which is so much better than being capped on consoles). This game will never be RTS game that sets the bar for all other RTS style games, far from it, BUT, this is infact one of the best RTS games around nowadays.

Firstly, you get THREE campaigns for three different factions, each with a very unique style. GDI which is basically your standard army relying on highly advanced tech to destroy your enemies *cough* Mammoth tanks OP *cough* . Then there is NOD (All hail Kane!), arguabley the one that takes the most skill, as you are usually going to end up using stealth units or surprise kamikaze runs in order to halt your more advanced enemies. They may not pack the biggest punch, but they have a really mean defense system which is every turtles dream and every player who likes to steamroll's nightmare. Then there is Scrin, take the ships from Stargate Atlantis and Independence day, throw in some Tripods from War of the worlds and some menacing alien-infantry and you have one of the most OP factions in any RTS ever. All campaigns are great and all have replay value, and trust me, when the difficulty is on hard, you will need an act of god to save you for almost every mission. All and all, the campaigns are really good and all are essentially a tutorial in some way for Skirmish mode. Straight to the point, Skirmish mode is your standard Team Deathmatch, you can do anything between 1v1 to 4v4, or if you want to be a god do a 1v7.

Now lets talk about the cons. One of the biggest problems in the game is MASSING, in order words, spamming the same unit over and over cause you can't be bothered to use some real strategy and want to steam roll every skirmish or mission. Whether its creating a moving fortress of 20 Mammoth tanks, swarming the skies with 1000 (slight exageration) Venoms or just flat out crucifying everything in your path with some Scrin aircraft or tripods, if you want to mass, this is your game. However, there is an amazing array of different units with different abilities that the AI uses to its full potential and it takes quite a bit of skill to combat it, try to experiment with different units, massing isn't fun. Next con is the difficulty system. Easy is too easy, its a curbstomp and its the setting you'd use to teach your little sibling how to play. Medium/Normal is a step up but after a few games you should be fine although you can't 1v2 or 1v3 against Medium AI's. Then theres Hard/Brutal, whatever hate-induced state the developers were on when they made this setting, they wanted you to lose. Its nearly impossible to take down a Brutal opponent, it took myself and 2 other friends about 40 minutes to kill a Brutal enemy AI, its honestly that hard unless you mass/turtle. If you like a challenge, this is were you get one. I once did two Brutal AI vs myself and five mediums, after 10 minutes three of my allies were dead and we only won cause I turtled and spammed the super weapons.

Lastly the multiplayer servers are down, there is some fan-supported servers around but the official ones are down (♥♥♥♥ YOU EA).

So heres the summary, if you want a game for really good campaign and endless amounts of fun with Skirmishes, this is worth it. Avoid massing for a real challenge and use the Mothership to wipe out the whole map if you want to end the map with a bang, pun intended.

8/10. KANE LIVES.

The Single Player Campaign (SPOILERS):

With 200+ hours on this account for this game; I'll make it quicker than I want it to be and I'll be providing a TL;DR at the bottom.

This game is beautiful. No, not just because of the graphics since that does not make a game great. I'll admit that being made in 2007: the graphics do hold very well to this very day. I'm talking about how the game feels to play, how much lore that you can unfold in this game and a very important point I will bring up later on.

The game itself is very easy to pick up and learn the basics such as what units do what, what your base does and many other things. As you progress through the story; you'll meet bonus objectives that you can complete for a different medal at the end (great for you completionists). The campaigns can have some very challenging moments for newer players but it will make you do what you're supposed to do: Come up with a strategy to win.

Notice that I said campaigns. You can play the GDI (Global Defense Initiative), NOD campaign and a short Scrin campaign. The last being unlocked once you have completed both of the other two campaigns.

This game supports free building (allowing you to build almost anywhere on the map except impassable terrain), there is no unit limit and there is some decent to good balance in this game.

Now, onto that point I mentioned earlier: It's the community. The C&C community has been part of me throughout my childhood and still is. People have constantly pushed out custom maps that have gamemodes for them such as No money, Art of Defense and Comp stomp. Command and Conquer Generals was my introduction to the community but not the series and I'm glad to see how much it has flourished.

If you wish to play this game online: Look into C&C Online. It's a community project that provides players to connect to their servers to play online so you can play with your friends or strangers. Downloading and installing custom maps is incredibly easy to do and can provide you more enjoyment in this game.

Now, here's another important piece of the community: Mods. There are tonnes of them that bring things from the older games or whatever the team behind the mod wanted. I've played dozens upon dozens of mods and because of that; this game has continued to be something I love to play and relax with.

TL;DR: I love this game and if you're wondering that if it is worth your time and money; I hope you do pick this amazing game up. This game has good replayability with custom maps and mods that you can find via Google.

Needless to say that this C&C fan will be giving this game a 10/10.

Tiberium Wars is in a lot of ways, the last hurrah of the C&C franchise. It is the last of the games to really stay true to the formula that made the series so successful but it was also the last of the series that failed to innovate and that is something that hurt it.

The great live action cutscenes make a return but instead of the wonderful b-movie quality of previous installments it is now little more than catwalk performances by semi-famous actors.

The gameplay is the same as in previous installments, although there has been some technical advancement you will immediately become comfortable with it. The poor unit AI and the lack of certain utility units common in other games does become frustrating rather quickly.

It is a good game if you liked the old C&C's in series but it is also a game that has become stagnant. A game that tries to innovate but fails every step of the way and although C&C will always hold a place in my heart, I am glad that the genre is advancing beyond it.

But there's a lot of variety here and the Nod Avatars are pretty sweet too.  No matter how you like to play, there's gonna be some units you'll love, some levels you'll love, and a few you'll love to hate.  As it should be.

One of the best C&C games so far, I have to honestly say that this game is twice better than Starcraft 2 and trillion times better than Starcraft 2 Heart of the Swarm. I used to be a Starcraft player, but Blizzard ruined the ♥♥♥♥ out of every ♥♥♥♥ing thing. So I changed my perspective on RTS genre, Westwood Studios is the best RTS maker of all times.
Their game may not be so competitve like Blizzard, but they are fast pace but FUN!
Competitiveness ruined the gaming industry, where it aimed only for FUN. C&C Tiberium War in this case exceeds most of its predecessors by being either fun (spamming units) and competitive. The AI in this game is very excellent and harder than Starcraft 2. The first time I played the campaign at easy level, the bots beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. In the skirmish game, the bots if you chose Steamroller, they will roll over you if in easy level.

Although the multiplayer is no longer supported by EA, you still can go to online forums and download software to help the multiplayer section.

The game is best at:
- Best cinematics (Blizzard looks cheesy, but Westwood looks serious)
- Amazing actors
- Stunning graphics
- Great soundtrack
- Large gamesize, it is beyond my expectation of previous games
- Dangerous AIs, they simply focus on wiping your most dangerous units
- Many special abilities
- Challenging missions with many bonuses that hardly find in any RTS game
- Best RTS Campaign of the decade (C&C games always pull me to be serious in watching briefing, tempting)
- Great Balance system (This new C&C fixed the unit spamming in Red Alert 2)
- Best modding community secondly after Skyrim Nexus (It composed of many foreigners, they are amazing)
- Tiberium Essence! The best mod that made this game perfect, you need to download it on DB.

Some flaws:
- Many special abilities (Old Red Alert 2 is easier, this new thing is quite hard to use)
- Chaotic graphic ( I feel the graphic is a little too oversaturated)
- AIs are quite dumb at pathfinding
- Still having some balancing flaws from the old C&C
- Harvester!
- Still no CABAL from Firestorm Crisis, I was waiting for an expansion on such amazing AI villain in video game history, yeah, ♥♥♥♥ EA.

Score: 96/100
Greatly Amazing, but underrated.

reviewText:
I have been a strategy game player all my life, I and can honesly say this is one of the worst. Sure there are great graphics and the cutscenes that glorify you, the commander, with well known science fiction actresses playing the rolls are certain to make you feel like a conquering hero. But beyond that the gameplay is nearly unplayable unless you are an expert. I was playing on normal up until act 5 when I just got way to tired of having to restart. Because once you make a mistake, there is no recovering.

The tiberium crystal economy is always too slow to keep up your war machine with the constant enemy advances. And the worst part of it is that you are basically on a timer. Because once you are out of the initial crystal piles, there is no way to keep up production because the crystal piles grow out of the ground at a slugs pace.

On top of that, there seems to be no way to build up defences to use a 'turtle up' strategy, even while you are trying to build up your initial forces. And because of that, enemies are constantly getting inside of your base and wreaking havok on your very weak structures that cost more than an arm and a leg.

On top of that, there seems no other way to win than to build up a massive force and then sweep the map. Because there is no real use for scouting and no long range siege abilities except on the absolute most expensive units, when it would be a much better idea just to build up a lot of mammoth tanks. You can forget about skirmishing as the enemy will always either have a large number of base defenses that will wipe out any small force or their troops will be in constant production coming out of their buildings so you wind up doing no real damage and lose everything.

I do not recommend this game to anybody, even if you are already bord of all your other games. Stick with the good old Age of Empires or Starcraft series for a much more enjoyable experience.

TL:DR; There are many great RTS out there, this isn't one. Save your money, but something else.

reviewText:
Note: I have this game on Origin with 335 hours prior to purchasing on Steam.

Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is a worthy addition to the C&C franchise. It runs well and is generally bug-free — though a few irritating bugs are present, such as: sometimes, while in a skirmish game against an AI, stealth is useless. Their units follow your stealthed units around as if the unit was visible.

The game butchered the 'tiberian' canon somewhat from the previous games. Originally, 'Tiberium' used to be some sort of organism; a plant that crystalizes minerals from the ground and emits poisonous gases. This entity was sent to the earth by the Scrin to transform Earth into a planet suitable for them. In this game, they completely changed the chemical composition of the entity. Instead of an alive plant-like organism, 'tiberium' is now a crystal that acts like some sort of lifeless radiative substance sent to Earth to crystalize the entire planet for mineral harvestation.

Aside from the canon, the storyline is... okay. It's not great, but if stories aren't your thing, it's passable. If you're joining the series without prior C&C experience, the story is not really that interesting.

As an RTS title, I would say it is disappointing. Work has gone into balancing and unit design, and generally works, but as a balance system alone, it is pathetic. In order to win, you need less strategy and more tank-rushing. Infantry are almost useless and aircraft aren't far behind.

A good point of consideration is the availability of mods, however. There are some mods that add desperately-needed balancing changes to make the game require an actual brain. There are also mods that boost the total hours you are going to get out of this title by converting the game to fit with unique themes, such as: Dune II, Cold War era, modern warfare, etc.

Conclusion
I would recommend this game only if you have been introduced to the C&C series prior to the release of this title. If were looking at it purely as an RTS, it does okay. You might want to pass it up if your standards are somewhat high. Otherwise, I suggest giving it a try. I love the game.

The first being the GDI's campaign and the second Brotherhood of Nod campaign but the third campaign (which i wont spoil here) is only unlocked after completing the first two campaigns.
Difficulty can range anywhere from cakewalk to seemingly impossible. This is mostly in part to the games latest patch which balances some units more but breaks others. Example would be the Mammoth Tank and Black Hand. The mission the Tank is introduced for you to use is supposed to be an easy one due to it being GDI's best land vehicle but after the patch the tank is not nearly as powerful as it should be which in turn makes the mission a lot tougher. The Black Hand is a flamethrower unit for Nod and being infantry are supposed to be weaker to anti infantry turrets but after the patch not even 3 anti infantry turrents can down one squad of them. Post patch the only effective way to deal with them is either aircraft bombings or attempting to run them over with a tank which they seem to be able to chew up effectively too.
Overall Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars is worth the buy along with its expansion pack Kanes Wrath. Its definitely one of the greatest Command and Conquer games out there alongside Command and Conquer Generals. I give C&C TW3 an 8/10.

You can't have a singleplayer skirmish without the AI spamming grenadiers/black hand/buzzers. All in all I'd give it a 7/10 because I loved the previous C&C games and EA did a good job of continuing the story for the Tiberium series, but it is lacking in some areas that could have been executed better.

Tiberium Wars is a simple, yet very fun RTS game.  There are 3 factions to choose from, each of which are very well structured, yet still have their unique advantages and disadvantages.  This balances the gameplay beautifully.  Many RTS games have very complex gameplay mechanics, which often turns off newcomers of the genre.  The gameplay in Tiberium Wars is very easy to grasp and the customizable AI gives you a fun, comfortable learning curve, but there is a downside to this feature.  Tiberium Wars lacks any innovative RTS features and doesn’t bring anything new to the table.  In addition, the limited amount of custom maps restricts the fun Tiberium Wars has to offer in skirmish mode.  Fortunately, these imperfections are easily overlooked with its incredibly satisfying gameplay that deserves the attention of any RTS fan or gamers new to the genre.

Command & Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars is among one of the most fun and addicting games I've ever played.
The story is a little bit wonky, apparently the Philadelphia being destroyed is a lot less of a big deal than it was last time, but this time I guess there wasn't a big fat tiberium missile looking to wreck everything, and an inexplicable gap between this one and Tiberian Sun which they did fill in later. Other than that however, it's fantastic (omg michael ironside <333).
The gameplay is quite amazing, very fun, though unit pathfinding is quite bad. Frequently, moving groups of units, mostly ground vehicles, will have them going all over the place, into different directions, and sometimes they'll just sit still and not move despite your orders to have them move. This can become frustrating very quickly, especially in skirmish and multiplayer games where this can delay an attack.

But overall, C&C3 is a brilliant game. Though it doesn't capture the dark and gloomy atmosphere of Tiberian Sun, somehow missing out the world looking like it was recently all on fire and the legendary ion storms, it is graphically stunning. From the maps in general down to individual units themselves, C&C3 looks just beautiful. It was a joy to play through.

Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is a worthy addition to the C&C franchise. It runs well and is generally bug-free — though a few irritating bugs are present, such as: sometimes, while in a skirmish game against an AI, stealth is useless. Their units follow your stealthed units around as if the unit was visible.

The game butchered the 'tiberian' canon somewhat from the previous games. Originally, 'Tiberium' used to be some sort of organism; a plant that crystalizes minerals from the ground and emits poisonous gases. This entity was sent to the earth by the Scrin to transform Earth into a planet suitable for them. In this game, they completely changed the chemical composition of the entity. Instead of an alive plant-like organism, 'tiberium' is now a crystal that acts like some sort of lifeless radiative substance sent to Earth to crystalize the entire planet for mineral harvestation.

Aside from the canon, the storyline is... okay. It's not great, but if stories aren't your thing, it's passable. If you're joining the series without prior C&C experience, the story is not really that interesting.

As an RTS title, I would say it is disappointing. Work has gone into balancing and unit design, and generally works, but as a balance system alone, it is pathetic. In order to win, you need less strategy and more tank-rushing. Infantry are almost useless and aircraft aren't far behind.

A good point of consideration is the availability of mods, however. There are some mods that add desperately-needed balancing changes to make the game require an actual brain. There are also mods that boost the total hours you are going to get out of this title by converting the game to fit with unique themes, such as: Dune II, Cold War era, modern warfare, etc.

Conclusion
I would recommend this game only if you have been introduced to the C&C series prior to the release of this title. If were looking at it purely as an RTS, it does okay. You might want to pass it up if your standards are somewhat high. Otherwise, I suggest giving it a try. I love the game.

So I can say this is one of my most favorite stratagy games.
As I am huge on strategy games.

For the combat,
It's your base combat game, but detailed to a good perfection.

Some examples are, well if you train infantry they might sit around a wall when they're near one.
And they each have some interesting about them rather it be the spot on voice acting or the unit crouching when getting shot at by heavy fire. There's a lot of small bits of animation posing and it really brings the infantry alive.

As for vehicles, they are your standard.
Except what I love about them is some can actually run over units.
And have interesting accuracy.

This allowing you to deter large swarms a of infantry by running them over with a tank.

As for factions
(I'm going to sum this up Horribly lmao)

You have the Brotherhood Of Nod,
They're stealth oriented but can become a major threat even without stealth.

You have the GDI,
They're army oriented, kinda earths defense force. Not much stealth but more tank like.

And the Scrin,
They're aliens and I can't describe them too well. They're faster at resource collecting with mediocre units (I presume?)

And that's all.
GDI<Scrin<Nod
Nod<GDI<Scrin
(As far as I think the circle of life for these guys go)

Now as for the game itself,
Great voice acting,
Frostbite 2 engine really tops off some of the details for the time of release,
And personally I can say this is close (besides for Kane's wrath and a few other C&C Titles released before C&C 4)
